headline.main: Tough Justice for Executives in Enron Era
headline.print_headline: Tough Justice For Executives In Enron Era

byline.original: By KURT EICHENWALD   and ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO

docs.snippet: The stories of Enron's ultimate demise may prove to be -- at least somewhat -- exaggerated.    Enron, which collapsed into bankruptcy in 2001 and had been expected to sell most of its assets, announced yesterday that it intended to retain interest...
docs.lead_paragraph: The stories of Enron's ultimate demise may prove to be -- at least somewhat -- exaggerated. Enron, which collapsed into bankruptcy in 2001 and had been expected to sell most of its assets, announced yesterday that it intended to retain interests in certain North American pipelines and form a company to own and operate them. For months, Enron, the energy company based in Houston, had been trying to determine which assets to sell to raise money to bring its bankruptcy case to an end. Last August, the company put its interests in 12 main assets, including the pipelines, on the block for auction.

headline.main: In Shift, Enron Will Retain Interests in Some Pipelines

docs.snippet: JONES MURPHY might not have noticed what his colleagues at the Williams Companies were doing if they had not been gloating.    Mr. Murphy, previously a Wall Street executive, had recently been hired as the director of emerging products at Williams...
docs.lead_paragraph: JONES MURPHY might not have noticed what his colleagues at the Williams Companies were doing if they had not been gloating. Mr. Murphy, previously a Wall Street executive, had recently been hired as the director of emerging products at Williams's headquarters in Tulsa, Okla., to help manage its trading risks. He was on the company's trading floor when he heard a commotion at the desk of Blake Herndon, director of risk management.
docs.abstract: Jones Murphy contends he was fired by Williams Companies, where he worked as risk manager, after repeatedly warning company that company had to reduce its risk in electricity and natural gas trading, especially with shaky counterparties like Enron; says company's employed accounting techniques that gave it great leeway to inflate profits on energy trading; also suggests that Williams succeeded in driving up gas prices in California in December 2000; Williams contends Murphy lacked understanding of company's business; Williams is now teetering -- its share price down sharply and its credit rating under scrutiny -- and plans to sell as much as $1.5 billion in equity and $3 billion in assets over next year to pare its $13 billion debt; photos; graph (L)

headline.main: A Collision On Risks Of Energy Trading

docs.snippet: Senate Democrats investigating the collapse of Enron are turning up the heat on the White House, with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman saying today that he plans to subpoena the Bush administration about its contacts with the company, which was once hi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats investigating the collapse of Enron are turning up the heat on the White House, with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman saying today that he plans to subpoena the Bush administration about its contacts with the company, which was once highly influential politically. The Justice Department task force leading the criminal investigation into Enron is, meanwhile, considering whether to expand its inquiry to include the company's energy-trading practices, according to a government official close to the task force.
docs.abstract: Senate Democrats investigating collapse of Enron Corp are turning up heat on Bush administration, with Sen Joseph I Lieberman saying that he plans to subpoena administration about its contacts with company, which was once highly influential politically; Lieberman says he has grown frustrated that White House appears unwilling to turn over all information Congress had sought; White House counsel Alberto R Gonzales says administration has been gathering information to begin turning over to Lieberman later this month; Sen Fred Thompson, ranking Republican on Government Affairs Committee, says he hopes committee is not tempted to pursue fishing expedition; Justice Department task force leading criminal investigation into Enron is considering whether to expand its inquiry to include company's energy-trading practices; prosecutors have begun informally to gather information about Enron executives and traders who helped shape trading strategies in California and to assess whether those strategies might have violated any laws; photos (M)

headline.main: Senate Democrats Escalate Efforts to Get White House To Disclose Enron Contacts

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Former Fed Chief Outlines Proposal to Save Andersen'' (front page, March 23):
docs.abstract: Harvey Kagan letter on March 23 article holds small accounting firm accused of Andersen-type irregularities would have been shut down

docs.snippet: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen filed a motion late yesterday seeking to block prosecutors from using a federal grand jury to continue investigating the document destruction that led to the firm's indictment on a charge of obstruction of justice.    I...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen filed a motion late yesterday seeking to block prosecutors from using a federal grand jury to continue investigating the document destruction that led to the firm's indictment on a charge of obstruction of justice. In the filing, the lawyers argue that federal prosecutors have improperly begun using the grand jury to gather evidence to bolster their prosecution of Andersen, which they say is impermissible after the filing of a criminal indictment.
docs.abstract: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen file motion seeking to block prosecutors from using federal grand jury to continue investigating document destruction that led to Andersen's indictment on charge of obstruction of justice; lawyers argue that federal prosecutors have improperly begun using grand jury to gather evidence to bolster their prosecution of Andersen, which they say is impermissible after filing of criminal indictment; filing contends Justice Department interviewed potential witnesses from Andersen before filing indictment; papers say prosecutors failed to compel testimony before grand jury from any of those witnesses (M)

headline.main: Grand Jury Being Misused As Investigator, Andersen Says

docs.snippet: In their first effort to turn the Enron collapse into an overt campaign issue, Democrats today unveiled a commercial attacking Elizabeth Dole, one of the Republicans' best-known Senate hopefuls, for attending a fund-raiser given by Kenneth L. Lay,...
docs.lead_paragraph: In their first effort to turn the Enron collapse into an overt campaign issue, Democrats today unveiled a commercial attacking Elizabeth Dole, one of the Republicans' best-known Senate hopefuls, for attending a fund-raiser given by Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron. The 30-second spot, sponsored by the North Carolina Democratic Party with financial assistance from the Washington-based Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, takes to task Mrs. Dole, the former presidential candidate who is the prohibitive favorite in the Republican primary for the North Carolina Senate seat being vacated by Jesse Helms. The Democrats have not yet chosen their Senate candidate.
docs.abstract: North Carolina Democratic Party unveils television commercial attacking Elizabeth Dole, favorite in Republican primary for North Carolina Senate seat being vacated by Jesse Helms, for attending fund-raiser given by former Enron Corp chairman Kenneth L Lay; Dole spokeswoman Mary Brown Brewer says it is sad that Democrats have already resorted to personal attacks ads (M)

headline.main: In Commercial, Elizabeth Dole Is Chastised For Enron Ties

docs.snippet: When the Enron Corporation made the last payment on a $250,000 pledge to the University of Texas Law School last February, the school's dean, William C. Powers Jr., added a handwritten note to his official response: ''Thank you for all you do for ...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Enron Corporation made the last payment on a $250,000 pledge to the University of Texas Law School last February, the school's dean, William C. Powers Jr., added a handwritten note to his official response: ''Thank you for all you do for us!'' Nearly a year later, Mr. Powers sits on Enron's board and heads an internal investigation of the partnerships that hid the company's losses. Mr. Powers was made a director in late October and was asked to lead the internal investigation. His committee is cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission on its investigation.
docs.abstract: William C Powers Jr, dean of University of Texas Law School, has sat on board of Enron Corp since October 2001 and heads internal investigation of partnerships that hid company's losses, and critics say he should consider giving up one or the other position, especially in view of other close ties between law school and Enron; Powers argues that none of his relationships with company and its executives affect his impartiality; photo (M)

headline.main: Questions Arise on Law School Dean's Enron Duties
headline.kicker: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: CLOSE TIES IN TEXAS

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Crony Capitalism, U.S.A.,'' by Paul Krugman (column, Jan. 15),  should not have relied on second-hand sources, including Red Herring Magazine, for information about the Carlyle Group....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Crony Capitalism, U.S.A.,'' by Paul Krugman (column, Jan. 15), should not have relied on second-hand sources, including Red Herring Magazine, for information about the Carlyle Group.
docs.abstract: Carlyle Group aide Chris Ullman letter disputes Paul Krugman's references to company in Jan 15 column on Enron Corp as example of crony capitalism

docs.snippet: Dynegy Inc. said tonight that it would acquire the valuable Northern Natural Gas pipeline from the Enron Corporation in a settlement of one dispute between the companies that had tried to merge last year.    Dynegy had claimed Enron signed away it...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dynegy Inc. said tonight that it would acquire the valuable Northern Natural Gas pipeline from the Enron Corporation in a settlement of one dispute between the companies that had tried to merge last year. Dynegy had claimed Enron signed away its right to the 16,500-mile pipeline system, which extends from Texas into the Midwest, in exchange for $1.5 billion invested in Enron before a proposed combination of the companies, which are competitors in the energy business, collapsed in late November.
docs.abstract: Dynegy Inc says it will acquire valuable Northern Natural Gas pipeline from Enron Corp in settlement of one dispute between companies that had tried to merge last year; Dynegy had claimed Enron signed away its right to 16,500-mile pipeline system, which extends from Texas into Midwest, in exchange for $1.5 billion invested in Enron before proposed combination of companies collapsed in November; Enron claimed Dynegy illegally terminated $9 billion deal and therefore had no right to pipeline; Dynegy says companies have agreed to close pipeline deal, with Enron having option to repurchase pipeline by June 30; Dynegy says settlement will not affect companies' bigger battle over failed merger agreement says it will pursue its claims that Enron breached that agreement (M)

headline.main: Dynegy to Get Enron's Natural Gas Pipeline
